title: No bubble trouble in commercial property
text:
(It’s also worth noting that Conry says the average annual inflows into the sector are between $35 billion and $40 million, so while it’s been a good year it is not one where you’d be worried about serious overheating.)

Chanticleer interviewed the always-entertaining Shane Oliver on stage, who as well as providing his thoughts on the latest series of The Bachelor – Oliver was a tad upset when Helena was left without a rose during the series, for those playing at home – he also provided some context about the yield environment.

Rewind to the 1980s when Oliver started his career, property yields across all classes were sitting somewhere between 8 per cent and 9 per cent, while bond yields were sitting around 14 per cent.

Today, global bond yields are just under 1 per cent and while residential property yields have tracked back towards 3 per cent, commercial property yields have only come back to about 5 per cent.

This gives Oliver comfort that what we are seeing in commercial asset values is far from silly and in fact, there may yet be some upside for commercial property in this current environment.

Steinberg also says it’s important to consider how the property sector would fare if conditions were to suddenly change.

It’s very different today to the conditions seen during the 1990s commercial property or the global financial crisis. Back in those periods, property companies couldn’t get debt with a tenure much longer than two or three years. In the current low-rate environment, there’s no shortage of cheap 20-year money around; Steinberg says Dexus’ average tenure is about seven years.

Advertisement

“If you have long-term debt you won’t get caught when the cycle turns,” he explained.

Steinberg is blunt about the outlook for the retail sector – there’s simply too much retail space in Australia, and the sector will need to think very carefully about the creation of future space.

Mirvac chief executive Susan Lloyd-Hurtwitz also sounded a warning for retailers, retail landlords and investors who are hoping to see the recent tax cuts and interest rates put a bounce in the sector.

The switch among consumers from necessity to choice is far more transformational than any short-term bump in economic conditions.

Nobody in this room ever has to go to a shop for anything, if you so desire,” Lloyd-Hurtwitz told the summit.

“That to me is a much more profound shift than stimulus and falling retail.”

This is not to say that Mirvac is giving up on the retail sector. Lloyd-Hurtwitz points to numerous examples around the world of online retailers pushing into physical retail. These moves are not necessarily designed to boost sales, she says, but rather about creating an environment to showcase brands in a way that can’t be done online.

“It’s a way to showcase, provide experiences, collect customers. Physical space still has a function – it will just change.”
description: Dexus chief executive Darren Steinberg says fears of an asset bubble in commercial property ignore the different conditions that exist today.
